sub_topic: Calculating the percent composition of inorganic compounds
message_1: What is the percent composition of sodium chloride (NaCl)? Show your work and round to the nearest tenth of a percent.
message_2:
To find the percent composition of sodium chloride (NaCl), we need to determine the mass of each element (sodium and chlorine) and then divide it by the total mass of the compound.

First, we need to find the molar mass of each element:
- Sodium (Na) has a molar mass of 22.99 g/mol.
- Chlorine (Cl) has a molar mass of 35.45 g/mol.

Now, we can find the molar mass of NaCl by adding the molar masses of Na and Cl:
Molar mass of NaCl = Molar mass of Na + Molar mass of Cl
Molar mass of NaCl = 22.99 g/mol + 35.45 g/mol
Molar mass of NaCl = 58.44 g/mol

Next, we will find the percent composition of each element in NaCl:
Percent composition of Na = (Molar mass of Na / Molar mass of NaCl) x 100
Percent composition of Na = (22.99 g/mol / 58.44 g/mol) x 100
Percent composition of Na ≈ 39.3%

Percent composition of Cl = (Molar mass of Cl / Molar mass of NaCl) x 100
Percent composition of Cl = (35.45 g/mol / 58.44 g/mol) x 100
Percent composition of Cl ≈ 60.7%

So, the percent composition of sodium chloride (NaCl) is approximately 39.3% sodium (Na) and 60.7% chlorine (Cl).
